title: Reverberation-based Features for Sound Event Localization and Detection with Distance Estimation
author: Davide Berghi (University of Surrey), Philip J. B. Jackson (University of Surrey), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces novel reverberation-based features which could enhance distance estimation tasks in audio and speech applications, relevant for Haohe Liu's research in audio processing.
background: Sound event localization and detection (SELD) aims to identify and locate sound events in three-dimensional space, incorporating the distance of the sound source.
contribution: This paper introduces reverberation-based features to solve the challenge of distance estimation in three-dimensional sound event localization, achieving improved distance accuracy and overall performance metrics.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily utilized direction of arrival estimation without considering source distance, leading to limited spatial accuracy in sound detection.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves distance estimation by incorporating features that analyze the direct-to-reverberant ratio and early reflections in audio signals.

key_innovation: It uniquely derives features from room reverberation effects to better predict sound source distances, a previously overlooked aspect in sound event localization.
real_world_impact: Enhancing distance estimation in SELD could significantly benefit applications such as human-robot interaction, augmented reality, and enhanced audio experiences.
limitations: The approaches may be influenced by room acoustics and require assumptions about the environments where sound events occur.

new_terms.reverberation: **Reverberation** refers to the persistence of sound in a space after the original sound has stopped, caused by multiple reflections off surfaces such as walls and floors.
new_terms.initial time delay gap (ITDG): **Initial time delay gap** is the time difference between the arrival of direct sound and the first significant reflection of that sound, used as a cue in distance perception.

open_sourcing: The code to extract features is available at [github.com/dberghi/SELD-distance-features](https://github.com/dberghi/SELD-distance-features)
